DOC.HEAD: Economists: Higher Energy, Food Prices Unlikely To Alter Fed Policy
Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `The federal ...,' to CORRECT federal funds rate to 9] sted 9.50 percent.
DOC.TEXT: The recent weather-related jump in energy and wholesale food prices should have a minimal impact on interest rates barring severe crop or oil shortages, but frigid temperatures in coming months could chill investors' inflation outlook, economists said Thursday. A record-setting cold snap in the past week has heavily damaged fruit and vegetable crops in such major growing areas as Florida and Texas and sent heating oil prices soaring in many parts of the country. The price of home heating oil and other fuels such as propane and kerosene have nearly doubled in some areas in the last two weeks as demand surged and supplies dwindled. Cold weather closed some refineries in Texas and Louisiana and curtailed crude oil shipments in some states. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, near-month heating oil futures jumped more than 40 percent in two weeks _ from 70.42 cents a gallon on December 15 for the near-term contract to 99.71 cents on Wednesday. Prices fell 3.31 cents to 96.40 cents a gallon on Thursday. But economists believe the current weather-related price rise is temporary. As such, it is unlikely to produce a long-term change in the inflation outlook that would prompt the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates in an attempt to stem rising prices. ``The Federal Reserve would be out of its mind if it changed economic policy because it's snowing in Florida,'' said Susan Lakatos, economist with Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``If the heating oil situation were so serious and widespread that it created shortages and closed factories we could expect some impact on interest rates. But there is no indication of that,'' she said. Nevertheless, the rise in heating oil prices and the deep freeze that has damaged citrus and other crops have confused the inflation outlook. Prospects for a drop in interest rates in early 1990 are being put on hold, analysts said. Higher energy and food prices have also altered the inflationary psychology of the credit and financial markets, with investors less sure the Fed would act to loosen credit and push interest rates lower, said John Silvia, economist with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. ``Instead of expecting the Fed to ease in January as before, people will be a lot less optimistic with respect to inflation, even though everyone knows it's a temporary situation,'' Silvia said, ``and the Fed will be slower to ease than it might have been.'' David H. Resler, chief financial economist for Nomura Securities International Inc., said the rise in heating oil prices may have contributed to the rise in short-term interest rates in recent days. The federal funds rate, the interest commercial banks charge each other for short-term loans, surged to 9] percent on Thursday from 8.19 percent last Friday after holding relatively steady during the rest of December. ``In a thin market with relatively few players around, anxieties run higher than normal,'' Resler said. But investor worries may be premature. Resler said that because food and fuel are considered nondiscretionary items in a household budget, higher prices for those produces could mean individuals simply would cut back on purchases in other areas. ``If I get stuck with oil bills 50 percent higher than usual, the harsh reality is that I will have to spend less on something else,'' Resler said. ``Over time that would exert downward pressure on other prices.'' Peter Greenbaum, economist with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said that food and energy normally are separated from other inflation indices because of their short-term volatility. And while higher prices for heating oil, citrus fruit and vegetables likely will push the December and January wholesale price indexes up, it should not amount to a sustained rise in prices, he said. ``The core inflation rate should be insulated from these effects,'' Greenbaum said.
